courseDescription: This course will introduce the properties of biomedical materials used as implants, prostheses, orthosis, and tissue-engineered materials as medical devices in contact with tissues and organs. Biocompatibility, immunological responses, wound healing, clotting cascade, surface compatibility and characterization of materials used for implantable medical devices will be introduced. Other topics such as ethical considerations and medical device regulatory mechanisms will be presented.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Collaboration with interdisciplinary teams in healthcare
Engaging in ethical discussions related to medical devices
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Managing regulatory compliance in medical device development
Leading discussions on ethical considerations in biomaterials

courseDescription: The purpose of this course is to achieve a broad overview of biomechanics, focused on the musculoskeletal system. Students will explore multiscale mechanics, including whole-body movement and mechanical properties of the structures in the musculoskeletal system.  Additionally, students will survey the experimental methods and computational modeling techniques used in biomechanics research.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Evaluation of mechanical properties in musculoskeletal structures

courseDescription: This course will introduce fundamental knowledge in regenerative medicine including therapeutic applications of biomaterials, tissue and stem cell engineering, gene therapy and bioelectrics, with emphasis on structure-function relationships of biologic systems. In addition to lecture, students will have opportunities for group discussions and presentations on milestone work related to tissue regeneration. Students will leave with a thorough understanding of true mammalian regeneration, wound healing/repair processes, and medical device milestones as related to human tissue regeneration and repair.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Presentations on milestone work related to tissue regeneration
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Medical device milestones evaluation as related to human tissue regeneration and repair
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leading presentations on milestone work related to tissue regeneration

courseTitle: Therapy and Function Models for Medical Simulation
courseDescription: This course introduces students to the main Modeling & Simulation models. (1) Anatomical modeling based on robust medical image segmentation and meshing methodologies. (2) A therapy model to determine the impact of a medical intervention by synthesizing the effect of a therapy on the patient’s tissues. (3) A collision model, which interacts with anatomy and therapy models, is used for haptics-driven simulations. This course will also explore physiological simulation and the use of finite elements to model biomechanics.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Synthesizing therapy effects on patient tissues

courseDescription: This course covers the electrical properties of cells and tissues as well as the use of electrical and magnetic signals and stimuli in the diagnosis and treatment of disease.  Typical topics to be covered include basic cell physiology, endogenous electric fields in the body, electrocardiography, cardiac pacing defibrillation, electrotherapy, electroporation, electrotherapy in wound healing.  In addition ultra-short electrical pulses for intracellular manipulation and the application of plasmas to biological systems will be covered.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding electrical properties of cells and tissues
Ability to apply plasmas to biological systems
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critical thinking in the use of electrical signals for diagnosis and treatment
Analyzing endogenous electric fields in the body
Problem-solving in electrotherapy for wound healing

courseDescription: Introduction to basic concepts in medical image analysis. Medical image registration, segmentation, feature extraction, and classification are discussed. Basic psychophysics, fundamental ROC analysis and FROC methodologies are covered. Cross-listed with ECE 462/MSIM 462.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analytical reasoning in medical image interpretation

courseTitle: Biomedical Applications of Low Temperature Plasmas
courseDescription: This course is cross listed with ECE and Biology. It is designed to be taken by senior undergraduate students and first year graduate students. The course contents are multidisciplinary, combining materials from engineering and the biological sciences. The course covers an introduction to the fundamentals of non-equilibrium plasmas, low temperature plasma sources, and cell biology. This is followed by a detailed discussion of the interaction of low temperature plasma with biological cells, both prokaryotes and eukaryotes. Potential applications in medicine such as wound healing, blood coagulation, sterilization, and the killing of various types of cancer cells will be covered.
Technical and Digital Skills: Knowledge of low temperature plasma sources
Interaction of low temperature plasma with biological cells
Medical applications such as wound healing, blood coagulation, sterilization, and cancer cell killing
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Collaboration between engineering and biological sciences
Effective communication of complex scientific concepts
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critical analysis of plasma-biological cell interactions
Problem-solving in applying plasma technology to medical treatments

courseTitle: Introduction to Mathematical Modeling in Physiology
courseDescription: This course introduces model development and model formulation with differential equations in physiology. Students will learn how to use Matlab to solve differential equations and visualize their results. The physiological focus will be on cellular physiology, particularly ion channel dynamics and homeostasis.

This course will introduce the properties of biomedical materials used as implants, prostheses, orthosis, and tissue-engineered materials as medical devices in contact with tissues and organs. Biocompatibility, immunological responses, wound healing, clotting cascade, surface compatibility and characterization of materials used for implantable medical devices will be introduced. Other topics such as ethical considerations and medical device regulatory mechanisms will be presented.

The purpose of this course is to achieve a broad overview of biomechanics, focused on the musculoskeletal system. Students will explore multiscale mechanics, including whole-body movement and mechanical properties of the structures in the musculoskeletal system. Additionally, students will survey the experimental methods and computational modeling techniques used in biomechanics research.

This course will introduce fundamental knowledge in regenerative medicine including therapeutic applications of biomaterials, tissue and stem cell engineering, gene therapy and bioelectrics, with emphasis on structure-function relationships of biologic systems. In addition to lecture, students will have opportunities for group discussions and presentations on milestone work related to tissue regeneration. Students will leave with a thorough understanding of true mammalian regeneration, wound healing/repair processes, and medical device milestones as related to human tissue regeneration and repair.
Technical and Digital Skills: Knowledge of tissue and stem cell engineering
Familiarity with gene therapy and bioelectrics
Ability to analyze structure-function relationships in biologic systems
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Skill in presenting milestone work related to tissue regeneration
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Ability to evaluate true mammalian regeneration processes
Analytical skills in understanding wound healing/repair processes
Critical thinking in analyzing medical device milestones for human tissue regeneration and repair

courseTitle: Therapy and Function Models for Medical Simulation
courseDescription: This course introduces students to the main Modeling & Simulation models. (1) Anatomical modeling based on robust medical image segmentation and meshing methodologies. (2) A therapy model to determine the impact of a medical intervention by synthesizing the effect of a therapy on the patient’s tissues. (3) A collision model, which interacts with anatomy and therapy models, is used for haptics-driven simulations. This course will also explore physiological simulation and the use of finite elements to model biomechanics.

This course covers the electrical properties of cells and tissues as well as the use of electrical and magnetic signals and stimuli in the diagnosis and treatment of disease.  Typical topics to be covered include basic cell physiology, endogenous electric fields in the body, electrocardiography, cardiac pacing defibrillation, electrotherapy, electroporation, electrotherapy in wound healing.  In addition ultra-short electrical pulses for intracellular manipulation and the application of plasmas to biological systems will be covered.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding electrical properties of cells and tissues
Application of plasmas to biological systems
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analyzing endogenous electric fields in the body
Intracellular manipulation using ultra-short electrical pulses

courseDescription: Introduction to basic concepts in medical image analysis. Medical image registration, segmentation, feature extraction, and classification are discussed. Basic psychophysics, fundamental ROC analysis and FROC methodologies are covered. Cross-listed with ECE 562/MSIM 562.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critical evaluation of medical image data
Analytical thinking in medical image processing

courseTitle: Biomedical Applications of Low Temperature Plasmas
courseDescription: This course is cross listed with ECE and Biology. It is designed to be taken by senior undergraduate students and first year graduate students. The course contents are multidisciplinary, combining materials from engineering and the biological sciences. The course covers an introduction to the fundamentals of non-equilibrium plasmas, low temperature plasma sources, and cell biology. This is followed by a detailed discussion of the interaction of low temperature plasma with biological cells, both prokaryotes and eukaryotes. Potential applications in medicine such as wound healing, blood coagulation, sterilization, and the killing of various types of cancer cells will be covered.
Technical and Digital Skills: Knowledge of low temperature plasma sources
Interaction of plasma with biological cells
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Collaborating across engineering and biological sciences disciplines
Presenting complex scientific concepts to diverse audiences
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analyzing the effects of low temperature plasma on different cell types
Identifying potential medical applications of plasma treatment
Evaluating the efficacy of plasma in wound healing and cancer treatment
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Coordinating experiments involving plasma and biological samples

courseDescription: This course will present the fundamentals of digital signal processing. Topics will include frequency domain analysis of discrete-time linear systems, sampling and reconstruction of signals, the Discrete Fourier Transform (DFT) and Fast Fourier Transform (FFT), and digital filter design and implementations. Practical applications and examples will be discussed. Problem solving using MATLAB is required.  Cross-listed with ECE 612.
Technical and Digital Skills: Frequency domain analysis of discrete-time linear systems

courseDescription: This course will be offered as needed, depending upon the need to introduce special subjects to target specific areas of master's-level specializations in biomedical engineering.
Individual project directed by the student’s professor in major area of study.
Technical and Digital Skills: Programming skills in major area of study
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critical thinking in major area of study
Problem-solving in research design and execution

courseDescription: Directed research for the master’s thesis.

This course covers the design of modern biomedical instruments including select diagnostic, assistive, therapeutic, prosthetic, imaging, and virtual devices and systems.  Techniques for mechanical, electrical, and chemical sensor and transducer design; stimulation and measurement; data acquisition; digital signal processing; and data visualization will be examined.

This course on mathematical modeling in human physiology emphasizes the development of mathematical models, their implementation, and the interpretation of simulation data.  The course focuses on cellular physiology, including membrane channels, excitability, and calcium dynamics; it also covers intercellular communication and spatially distributed systems.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Identification of patterns in physiological processes
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Coordination of team efforts in model creation

courseDescription: This course presents engineering techniques for the restoration and augmentation of human function via direct interactions between the nervous system and artificial devices, with particular emphasis on brain-computer interfaces.  Novel interfaces, hardware and computational issues, and practical and ethical considerations will also be covered.
Technical and Digital Skills: Hardware integration for nervous system interactions
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective communication of technical concepts to non-technical audiences
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Identifying and resolving hardware and software issues in neural interfaces
Critical evaluation of neural data for accurate interpretation
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Project management for neural engineering initiatives
Leading teams in the development of neurotechnology solutions

courseDescription: This course cover fundamental principles and properties of biomedical materials used as implants, prostheses, orthosis, and tissue-engineered materials as medical devices in contact with tissues and organs. Advanced concepts of biocompatibility and material characterization will be discussed. Physiological response factors associated with materials and implanted devices used in the human body will be presented, including immunological responses, wound healing, clotting cascade and surface compatibility. Other topics such as ethical considerations and medical device regulatory mechanisms will be discussed.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding fundamental principles of biomedical materials
Knowledge of properties of implants, prostheses, orthosis, and tissue-engineered materials
Understanding physiological response factors associated with materials in the human body
Familiarity with surface compatibility of materials
Knowledge of medical device regulatory mechanisms
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective communication of complex material concepts
Ability to discuss ethical considerations in biomedical materials
Presentation skills for conveying information on medical devices
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analytical skills for assessing material properties
Problem-solving abilities for physiological response challenges
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Understanding regulatory compliance in medical device development
Leadership skills in managing materials research projects

courseDescription: This course provides students important tools and experience in the vital grantsmanship area, which is needed to succeed in the competitive academic landscape. Students will be exposed to information regarding major predoctoral fellowships including NIH, NSF, DoD, and AHA, culminating in a grant proposal submission to the appropriate institution.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of NIH, NSF, DoD, and AHA fellowships

courseDescription: This course covers a range of active research topics in regenerative medicine, including therapeutic applications of biomaterials, tissue and stem cell engineering, gene therapy and bioelectrics, with emphasis on structure-function relationships of biological systems. Upon completion of the course students should leave with a thorough understanding of biological systems structure-function relationships and associated biomimetic therapeutic approaches in regenerative medicine.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critical evaluation of structure-function relationships in biological systems

courseDescription: Well-designed graphical media capitalizes on human facilities for processing visual information and thereby improves comprehension, memory, inference, and decision making. This course teaches techniques and algorithms for creating effective visualizations based on principles and techniques from graphic design, visual art, perceptual psychology and cognitive science. Both users and developers of visualization tools and systems will benefit from this course.
The course will introduce students to the responsible conduct of science and scientific research.

courseTitle: Computational and Statistical Methods in Biomedical Engineering
courseDescription: This course covers the theoretical foundation and application of commonly used techniques in biomedical engineering.  Topics include linear algebra, partial differential equations, regression analysis, applied probabilities, multivariate distributions, Bayesian statistics, hypothesis tests, multiple comparisons, ANOVA, solution of non-linear equations, numerical methods and optimization.  Programming software will be used to perform simulations and analyze biomedical data.
Technical and Digital Skills: Programming in software for simulations and data analysis

courseDescription: Bioelectrics is a new field encompassing both the science and technology of applying electrical stimuli to biological systems. This course covers the pulsed power technology that is required to generate electrical stimuli as well as the biological responses they evoke in cells and tissues. Particular emphasis is placed on the medical applications of bioelectrics, including tumor ablation, gene electrotransfer, wound healing, decontamination with cold plasma, and treatment of cardiac arrhythmias.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Assessment of electrical stimuli efficacy in cells and tissues
Optimization of bioelectrics protocols for specific applications

courseDescription: This course will give an overview of the structure and dynamics of biomembranes, the ion channels that are embedded in them, and the electrical properties of biomembranes. Topics include molecular dynamics modeling of biomembranes, membrane damage and repair, ion channel dynamics and their experimental assessment using patch clamping, and excitability in neurons and cardiomyocytes.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Presenting scientific findings to diverse audiences
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analyzing membrane damage and repair mechanisms
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Managing lab protocols and data organization

courseDescription: Course explores hands-on exposure to state-of-the-art algorithms in medical image analysis, which builds on open-source software (Insight Segmentation and Registration Toolkit - ITK), as well as the principles of medical image acquisition in the modalities of clinical interest. Medical imaging modalities - X-rays, CT, and MRI/ITK image pipeline; image enhancement, feature detection; segmentation - basic techniques, feature-based classification and clustering, graph cuts, active contour and surface models; surface and volume meshing; registration - transformations, similarity criteria; shape and appearance models are all explored and discussed in this course.
Technical and Digital Skills: Hands-on experience with Insight Segmentation and Registration Toolkit (ITK)
Understanding of medical image acquisition principles
Segmentation methods including basic techniques, feature-based classification, clustering, graph cuts, active contour and surface models
Registration techniques including transformations, similarity criteria
Knowledge of shape and appearance models
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critical evaluation of medical image analysis algorithms
Identifying and addressing issues in image processing pipelines
Applying appropriate segmentation and registration techniques based on medical imaging modalities
Troubleshooting and debugging in medical image analysis

courseDescription: Principles and techniques of two-dimensional processing of images.  Concepts of scale and spatial frequency.  Image filtering in spatial and transform domains.  Applications include image enhancement and restoration, image compressing, biomedical imaging for diagnosis of disease, and image segmentation for computer vision.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critical evaluation of image processing results
Problem-solving in image enhancement and restoration
Analytical thinking in biomedical imaging diagnosis

courseDescription: The purpose of this course is to achieve a broad overview of biomechanics, focused on the musculoskeletal system. Students will explore multiscale mechanics, including whole-body movement and mechanical properties of the structures in the musculoskeletal system.  Additionally, students will survey the experimental methods and computational modeling techniques used in biomechanics research.
Technical and Digital Skills: Analyzing mechanical properties of musculoskeletal structures
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Collaborating with peers on biomechanics projects

courseDescription: A broad introduction to the field of cellular biomechanics. Topics include overview of cell architecture, cytoskeleton, adhesion and molecular motors, biomolecular/biopolymer dynamics and mechanics, techniques to measure cell mechanical properties, techniques to mechanically stimulate cells, models of cell mechanical behavior, mechanobiology and mechanotransduction. Will include discussion of classic and current research articles.  Course content will aim to cater to students with diverse backgrounds – students with biological science background will be exposed to physical science concepts and analysis; students with engineering/physical science background will be exposed to biological phenomena and concepts.
Technical and Digital Skills: Knowledge of cytoskeleton structure and function
Ability to analyze biomolecular and biopolymer dynamics
Proficiency in techniques to measure cell mechanical properties
Skills in techniques to mechanically stimulate cells
Understanding models of cell mechanical behavior
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective communication of complex scientific concepts
Collaboration with individuals from diverse backgrounds
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Problem-solving in integrating biological and physical science concepts
Analytical skills in interpreting experimental data
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Ability to lead discussions on research articles
Organizing group projects involving interdisciplinary approaches

courseDescription: Special courses covering selected graduate-level topics in biomedical engineering.
This course allows students to develop specialized expertise by independent study (supervised by a faculty member).

This course covers the design of modern biomedical instruments including select diagnostic, assistive, therapeutic, prosthetic, imaging, and virtual devices and systems.  Techniques for mechanical, electrical, and chemical sensor and transducer design; stimulation and measurement; data acquisition; digital signal processing; and data visualization will be examined.

The course focuses on cellular physiology, including membrane channels, excitability, and calcium dynamics; it also covers intercellular communication and spatially distributed systems.

Novel interfaces, hardware and computational issues, and practical and ethical considerations will also be covered.
Technical and Digital Skills: Hardware implementation for nervous system interactions
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Presenting technical concepts to non-technical audiences
Collaboration with interdisciplinary teams on neural engineering projects
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Identifying and troubleshooting hardware/software issues in neural interfaces
Evaluating ethical implications of neural engineering advancements
Analyzing data from neural recordings for insights
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leading neural engineering projects from conception to execution
Managing resources effectively for neural interface development

Physiological response factors associated with materials and implanted devices used in the human body will be presented, including immunological responses, wound healing, clotting cascade and surface compatibility. Other topics such as ethical considerations and medical device regulatory mechanisms will be discussed.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of fundamental principles of biomedical materials
Familiarity with medical device regulatory mechanisms
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective presentation of complex technical information
Ability to discuss ethical considerations related to biomaterials
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Problem-solving related to wound healing and clotting cascade
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Ability to lead discussions on biocompatibility and material properties
Organizing and facilitating discussions on medical device regulatory mechanisms

courseDescription: This course provides students important tools and experience in the vital grantsmanship area, which is needed to succeed in the competitive academic landscape. Students will be exposed to information regarding major predoctoral fellowships including NIH, NSF, DoD, and AHA, culminating in a grant proposal submission to the appropriate institution.
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Team coordination for collaborative research projects

Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding structure-function relationships of biological systems
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Applying research findings to develop new therapies
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leading research projects in regenerative medicine
Managing team dynamics in a research setting

courseDescription: Well-designed graphical media capitalizes on human facilities for processing visual information and thereby improves comprehension, memory, inference, and decision making. This course teaches techniques and algorithms for creating effective visualizations based on principles and techniques from graphic design, visual art, perceptual psychology and cognitive science. Both users and developers of visualization tools and systems will benefit from this course.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Collaboration with developers and users of visualization tools
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leading and guiding teams in visualization design and development

courseDescription: The course will introduce students to the responsible conduct of science and scientific research.

Programming software will be used to perform simulations and analyze biomedical data.
Technical and Digital Skills: Programming in a scientific computing software (e.g., MATLAB, R)
Numerical methods for solving differential equations
Simulation techniques for biomedical data analysis

Technical and Digital Skills: Hands-on experience with medical image analysis algorithms
Using Insight Segmentation and Registration Toolkit (ITK)
X-ray, CT, and MRI image processing
Segmentation methods including graph cuts and active contour models
Surface and volume meshing in medical images
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Collaborating on medical image analysis projects
Effective communication of image analysis results
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critical evaluation of medical image analysis algorithms
Applying feature-based classification in medical images
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Project management in medical image analysis
Leading a team in image processing tasks

courseDescription: Special courses covering selected graduate-level topics in biomedical engineering.
This course allows students to develop specialized expertise by independent study (supervised by a faculty member).
Directed research for the doctoral dissertation.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Collaboration with research advisors and peers

courseDescription: This course is a pass/fail course doctoral students may take to maintain active status after successfully passing the candidacy examination.  All doctoral students are required to be registered for at least one graduate credit hour every semester until their graduation.
